subject: ADCSensor: Add PollRate and fix PowerState Always
commitMessage:
ADCSensor: Add PollRate and fix PowerState Always

    If set "PowerState" as "On" then there will create the handler to
check the host state is running or not. However, "PowerState" with
default "always" will not create the handler and cause ADCSensor crashed
by function isPowerOn when calling function checkThresholdsPowerDelay.
    For example, in our platform, we have only one ADCSensor which is
for p3v battery and need to be updated once per day.

Tested:
Test the threshold low/high for the following test case by using
"busctl set-property" to trigger threshold event and checking the
time in "ipmitool sel elist".
1. one sensor with PowerState is Always:
   When trigger low threshold it will delay 5 seconds to assert
   threshold event and the service is still alive.
   When trigger high threshold it will immediately assert the threshold
   event.
2. one sensor with other PowerState("On","BiosPost") will have the same
   behavior with case 1.

Test the following polling time by adding log in function updateValue:
PollRate not write in configuration: polling time is 0.5 sec.
PollRate with zero (value 0): polling time is 0.5 sec.
PollRate with negative value (value -1.0): polling time is 0.5 sec.
PollRate with positive value (value 2.0): polling time is 2.0 sec.

Signed-off-by: Jeff Lin <JeffLin2@quantatw.com>
Change-Id: I9044dd3b3844161721134f30a4de3229602a9172

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as d9cd7040e93337279c7d2939214f041e5f6ab447 by Ed Tanous
Follow 50/72 rule for commit messages and title.
Thanks for reminding.
Tested field?

We verified this two implementations on our platform.
1. Verify the implement of Interval, Gain and Offset by applying
   entity-manager with modifying these keywords and supervising the
   Sensors log.
   Check the SDR and verify the value is pass.
2. Verify the change in function StartTimer by confirming that ADCSensor
   will not get crash with throwing error "Power Match Not Created" and
   update once per sensor polling time when setting "PowerState" as
   "Always".
   Check if the daemon will not throwing exception and check the SDR is
   pass.
How does gain differ from scale factor?  They look very similar.

It looks like that scaleFactor is used to be degradation for sensor by
dividing the raw value. However, we have some sensor taking Gain value
which is used to multiply the raw value. Therefore, we think the meaning
of scaleFactor might not be equal to gain value and if we put the
reciprocal of gain value into scaleFactor there might cause some
deviation, for example, gain value is 3.
Here is the reference from phosphor-hwmon
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-hwmon/blob/94555352240ba7ac577a7017c0719cd9bbeb7a23/sensor.cpp#L107

> It looks like that scaleFactor is used to be degradation for sensor by
> dividing the raw value. However, we have some sensor taking Gain value
> which is used to multiply the raw value. Therefore, we think the meaning
> of scaleFactor might not be equal to gain value and if we put the
> reciprocal of gain value into scaleFactor there might cause some
> deviation, for example, gain value is 3.

A gain value of 3 would be a scaleFactor of 0.333333

> Here is the reference from phosphor-hwmon
> https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-hwmon/blob/94555352240ba7ac577a7017c0719cd9bbeb7a23/sensor.cpp#L107

If we really need to have gain, then I'd like to see scaleFactor removed, and completely replaced with gain, but I suspect that's not worth the effort.
Please split these into 3 patches, and provide each with a similar depth of commit message you've provided here.

Due to adding the same features, we push these changes together.
Thanks for your advising, we will split this into four pathches, three
for adding features in different sensors and one for fixing ADCSensor
crash when no sensor has "PowerState" is "On".
Tested?
I will update in commit message.
Updates to the entity-manager schema files will also be required to effect this change.
Ok. We will work on it.
gainFactor is the same thing as scaleFactor.  Please use the existing interfaces.

This seems like a low high scalefactor for a battery, and it's also odd that it's exactly 1/3.  Please double check your schematics to make sure this is what you intended, and that your math is correct.  WIth that said, this wont hold up your review.
This test case is specific for varifying our implement of PollRate and Offset with gain is 3. That's why we set ScaleFactor as 0.333333.

whitespace issue.

Also, 1000 as an offset?   that seems like an issue.  Please represent your numbers in the core units.  So 1.0 would induce an offset of 1 volt, -1.0 would reduce the output by 1 volt.

Also, generally 3.3V batteries don't have an offset in comparison with the onboard ADC, so this seems a bit odd to see.  You might want to verify that's what you intended.

Note: see below, I commented on your math equation where it needs to change.

Since in phosphor-hwmon, the raw data is directly calculated by gain and offset at first, we are used to setting Offset as a multiple of 1000.
I will change this with fixing the math formula.
Actually, ADC sensor in our platform do not have offset. However, we think making offset be customizable might make much more elastic to configurate ADCSensor.

> Since in phosphor-hwmon, the raw data is directly calculated by gain and offset at first, we are used to setting Offset as a multiple of 1000.

With respect, this is not phosphor-hwmon.  entity-manager chooses units that are in human facing intervals.  If you're porting phosphor-hwmon parameters to entity-manager, they will need to be converted.

> I will change this with fixing the math formula.
> Actually, ADC sensor in our platform do not have offset. However, we think making offset be customizable might make much more elastic to configurate ADCSensor.

If you have no use cases that require offset, please hold off adding them until you have use cases that actually require it to be different per systems.
I get it. I remove Offset for ADCSensor.

Please call this "PollRate" and make its units in seconds with a floating point number.

I feel like that would be more clear as to what the parameter does, and goes more in line with OpenBMCs dbus interfaces, which generally represent things in non-unit representations.
Ok. I will improve this feature.
"offset" is probably a better description without the word factor.
Done

This math looks wrong.  I suspect you should be doing:

(rawValue / sensorScaleFactor) / scaleFactor + offset
Done
Doesn't look like you actually use this anywhere....

In our platform, we have only ADC, PSU and Hwmon Temp sensors need to customize the polling sensor time for now. I'm not sure if it is better to add a feature in class Sensor and make all type of sensor be able to modify PollRate.

> In our platform, we have only ADC, PSU and Hwmon Temp sensors need to customize the polling sensor time for now. I'm not sure if it is better to add a feature in class Sensor and make all type of sensor be able to modify PollRate.

That's fine, but I think you misunderstood me.  You didn't use this variable to actually adjust the poll rate, you just added it to the struct.  This needs to initialize waitTimer.

I'd like to keep each sensor types wait timer local, as there tends to be sensor-specific changes (like power state monitoring) that needs to adjust the timer on a per-type basis.
it is used here : https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/38446/9/src/ADCSensor.cpp#199

sensorPollMs is used to receive pollRate and turn to milliseconds.
Then send the polling time to waitTimer.
ah, I see now.  It didn't show up in the diff.  Fine as is.

This looks incorrect, and will fail for sensors that have any other type of readstate setting.

Please rework and correct.

For now dbus-sensors only support three type (on, biosPost and always) for PowerState defined in Utils.hpp and these types are enough for our platform.
Since the readingStateGood will always return true when PowerState is Always, we modify this change to make the sensor with PowerState is always will directly check threshold like the other dbus-sensors.
I have added three test case for double check.

I am wondering whether there will be a case that even if a sensor is PowerState::always, we still want to do the PowerDelay. Plus, if checkThresholdsPowerDelay can crash, fix should be done in that function instead of relying on this check before the function call.
To make ADCSensor with PowerState::always be able to use checkThresholdsPowerDelay, we move readingStateGood form sensor.hpp to Utils.hpp and replace the isPowerOn function.
If powerstate::always is set, PowerDelay is irrelevant, because the sensors won't react to power state changes, so there's nothing to "delay" from.
Thanks for fixing the code path that can lead to crash even though it is not an issue currently.
naming convention
use constexpr in the beginning of the file : pollRateDefault something like that.
Done
Done

If use "sensor->readingStateGood()" here, then readingStateGood can stay in sensors.hpp.
I think that would be cleaner.

We had tried this before and it cannot work because there is a struct Sensor defined in Thresholds.hpp and readingStateGood locates in struct Sensor in Sensor.hpp.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/38446/14/include/Thresholds.hpp#14
It seems the Sensor in Thresholds.hpp is only used to pass the pointer of Sensor and not support for the function defined in Sensor.hpp.
Therefore, we move this function to make it available in Thresholds.hpp.
This function can be moved to Threshold.cpp to resolve the issue
This is a better solution, thanks!
same as other patch, may want to add a minimum PollRate
I add a limit to prevent the pollRate value is negative or equal to 0 (act like for loop).
Do you want skip the sensor or use the default poll rate when this field is misconfigured?

I used to think that it might be better to skip the sensor with wrong configuration.
But setting wrong pollRate seems no need to skip the sensor.
I update patch that will use the default poll rate here.
May I ask where the code is in EntityManager to get this config and present it on DBus?

https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/c7c5de795cf672797ae35965e95642dd1fc39363/src/EntityManager.cpp#L628
I think this function will generate all properties and corresponding value configured in json.
Then dbus-sensors will search and get the specific property it wants from entity-manager.

OK, then I would suggest make it an "official" schema in entity-manager.
Btw, I would prefer to use milli-second here, and possibly name it "PollInterval", e.g. "PollInterval": 3000

What do you think?

You can reference the comment message of patch 7 and 8.
The value in entity-manager have their unit, thus I think "PollRate" looks fine to have "second" as unit.
Remaining the word "Interval" in this name might cause the misusage of this property for someone who use phosphor-hwmon before.

> OK, then I would suggest make it an "official" schema in entity-manager.
> Btw, I would prefer to use milli-second here, and possibly name it "PollInterval", e.g. "PollInterval": 3000

In other places we've used seconds, as it doesn't require explicit documentation or postfixes.  Lets be consistent.

> 
> What do you think?
